item.title: 'Brotherless Night,' an ambitious novel about Sri Lankan civil war, wins $150K prize
item.description: The Carol Shields Prize for Fiction is a relatively new literary award given to women and nonbinary authors. This year's winner is V.V. Ganeshananthan for her book Brotherless Night.

item.title: Trapped in Rafah, U.S. medical volunteers say they can't save lives and can't evacuate
item.description: At the European Hospital in Rafah, there are shortages of pain medication, antibiotics, even bandages, American volunteers say they are unable to save lives — and unable to evacuate to safety.

item.title: Melinda French Gates resigns as co-chair from the Gates Foundation
item.description: French Gates says she is "immensely proud" of the work of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, and the decision to step down as co-chair was not easy. Her last day is June 7.

item.title: A Girl Scouts troop offers hope and 'sisters for life' for migrant children
item.description: Girl Scouts Troop 6,000 in New York City helps migrant girls establish connections and a platform to start a new life in a new country but also equips them with crucial life skills.

item.title: Why protesters in Georgia are opposed to a 'foreign agents' law and why it matters
item.description: More than 50,000 people took to the streets of the capital city Tbilisi over the weekend to protest against proposed legislation that critics say is modeled on a Russian law used to crush dissent.

item.title: Russia Makes Surprising Gains in Ukraine
item.description: Russia launched a surprise new offensive in northeast Ukraine, near the second largest city of Kharkiv. Russian troops are continuing to advance, we get the latest from our Ukraine correspondent. And in another development in that war, Russia's President Putin replaced the country's defense minister. We get context on both events from a retired U.S. Lieutenant Colonel who used to oversee European affairs at the National Security council.

item.description: Shares in the video game retailer more than doubled at one point after a prominent meme stock investor made his first online posting in about three years.

item.title: As the FDA evaluates ecstasy treatment for PTSD, questions mount about the evidence
item.description: Clinical trials of MDMA have been promising, but concerns have emerged about the quality of the research. A June hearing scheduled by the Food and Drug Administration is likely to address them.

item.title: A hidden danger in Gaza; a Haitian gang leader speaks up
item.description: Even if Israel and Gaza agree to a cease-fire, unexploded ordnance could continue to kill and maim Palestinians in Gaza for years. A Haitian gang leader says he's ready for a long fight.

item.title: Haiti's notorious gang leader, Barbecue, says his forces are ready for a long fight
item.description: Barbecue is the man who convinced many of Haiti's gangs to stop fighting each other and start fighting the government. He spoke to NPR about his latest plans.
